name: 5-methyl-3-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)-1H-pyrazole
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2485
Reason: 5-methyl-3-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)-1H-pyrazole has a melting point that we can compare to benzene's melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be the 1-methyl-3-phenyl-1H-pyrazole moiety, which has a melting point of around 100°C due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The trimethylphenyl group (C1(C)C) adds rigidity and molecular weight, contributing around +30 to +50°C. The methyl group (C) adds a slight increase in molecular weight and volume, raising the melting point by +5 to +10°C. The pyrazole ring itself can also contribute to the melting point due to its rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +20 to +30°C.
